Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Dynamic Networks: Learning, Inference, and Prediction with Nonparametric Bayesian Methods

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Complex networks are all around us. They can be physical, biological, social, and virtual. All the species in the world live in societies that can be represented as networks. Almost all complex systems, natural or man-made, are networks of interconnected components. The principal ingredients of all networks are their nodes and the links among the nodes. Most networks change with time. New nodes can be created and old ones can be eliminated. Similarly, new links can be established and existing ones removed. The nodes can form communities which they may leave later in time. The nodes may join another community or create a new one. Communities can emerge and disappear. All these phenomena can create very rich network dynamics. Understanding the common principles of these dynamics, the time-varying network structures and the functionalities that regulate network behaviors is of foremost importance in many fields of science and engineering. The theory that addresses these phenomena is a part of Network Science.

One of the main objectives of Network Science is to exploit statistical signal processing for inferential modeling of physical, biological, and social phenomena. The aspirations are to improve the understanding and prediction of these phenomena. In this project the investigator proposes to advance Network Science by introducing novel models for dynamic networks and novel ways for making inference and learning about them. The PI proposes to work with a methodology where the complexity of the network model is not predefined a priori but instead, it is determined by the observed data. Furthermore, the investigator proposes to work with Monte Carlo-based methods that can meet the most difficult challenges of the models in terms of their nonlinearities and dimensionalities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The world we live in is a very complex network of a huge number of interacting components. This network is composed of simpler networks that are still very complex, and in nature, they can be physical, biological, social, cognitive, semantic, or engineered. The networks are composed of nodes and links (vertices or connections) between the nodes. Typically, the networks are dynamic in that the number of nodes changes with time as do the links between the nodes. The study of networks is at the center of interest of an academic field known as Network Science.  The main objective of Network Science is representations of networks that describe phenomena of interest and their improved understanding and prediction. 

The research in this project aimed at making advances in various aspects of the science of dynamic networks. The overarching framework of the research was based on the theory of probability, and more specifically on Bayes’ theory. One can show that by using this theory information in data is processed optimally. Bayes’ theory is based on a probabilistically consistent representation of available knowledge about unknowns of interest and the amount of uncertainty contained in this knowledge. With Bayes’ theory all the results are provided in terms of probability distributions. These distributions contain all the information about the unknowns of interest, e.g., the parameters that describe the network models.

Intellectual merit: We addressed problems of how to discriminate among models that describe the growth of networks, how to discover causality in networks, and how nodes can maximize learning by exchanging information with neighboring nodes. Some of the proposed methods meet the most difficult challenges posed by nonlinearities and dimensionalities of adopted models.

One problem that was researched was the selection of the best model from a set of models that describe how a given network grows in time. From snapshots of the network at different instants of time (the number of its nodes and the links between the nodes), the objective was to determine which model was most accurate. The proposed solution was obtained by using a model selection scheme which decides on the best model by relying on the predictive powers of the respective models. The validity of the proposed solution was validated with numerous simulations.

A related problem is the estimation of how a given network has grown to a current size with all of its nodes and links without having any historical data about the network. For a given model, the proposed solution provides the most likely growth of the network.

In studying networks, understanding the interactions among its nodes is very important. The interactions, if they exist, can be bidirectional or unidirectional. For example, if one focuses on two interacting nodes, A and B, the question is if A influences B only, B influences A only, or if they influence each other. To make inference about the type of link between such nodes, Yule-Simon processes have been invoked. These are a special type of random processes that have the property of preferential attachment which under suitable conditions can generate power law distributions of interarrival times that are so common in nature. Various models of interaction based on these processes have been proposed and investigated. They have also been used to quantify the strength of interaction between two nodes.

Another important area of network science is how information diffuses over networks in time. In the project, various implementations of Bayesian inference in networks of collaborating nodes have been studied. In these networks, nodes share information in the form of measurements, estimates, or probability distributions with neighboring nodes and incorporate this information into their own knowledge about the unknowns of interest. Optimal approaches for modifying the current knowledge of the nodes have been investigated and many methods have been proposed. They range from fully analytical to purely computational methods, the latter being appropriate for highly challenging models.

Broader impacts: The PI has mentored several PhD students whose work has been within the scope of the project. Two of them graduated and one is about to complete her work. About half of the PhD students have been female students. Further, besides disseminating the findings of the work in 15 journal papers, 34 conference/workshop papers, and two book chapters, the PI co-edited a book on the subject of the project. It is entitled “Cooperative and Graph Signal Processing: Principles and Applications” and published by Elsevier in 2018. The book addresses several areas of Network Science. The PI also made a large number of presentations on the research of the project at conferences, workshops, and universities. Some of the methods that have been studied have direct applications in various types of networks including the Internet of Things, sensor networks, social networks, and biological networks.
